name: Sennheiser HE-1
comment: Mostly neutral, slight bass lift, highly resolving and natural both in tone and timbre. The world's best headphone.

name: Hifiman Shangri-La Jr
comment: A tad too shouty for my tastes, but far less offensive tonal characteristics than the average estat.

name: Hifiman Susvara
comment: Subtle refinements to the already-great HE1000 makes this arguably the best planar in the world.

name: Final D8000 Pro
comment: Highly resolving headphone with solid imaging capabilities, limited by its somewhat wonky tonality.

name: Audio Technica ATH-L5000
comment: Quirkiness not unexpected of an Audio Technica; arguably their worst closed-back. Sure took an L on this one.

name: Final Audio D8000
comment: High treble-to-midrange contrast makes things sound shrill and borderline-sibilant.

name: Focal Utopia
comment: Solid tuning with close to top-tier resolution. An inoffensive all-rounder that lives up to its reputation.

name: Audeze LCD-24
comment: A slight tonal improvement over the LCD-4, but also comes with a slight hit in resolution.

name: Hifiman HE1000se
comment: Basically a brighter and slightly shoutier version of the OG; may be a little too intense for some.

name: DCA Voce
comment: Wonky, honky, whatever you want to call it. Probably the worst e-stat I've heard.

name: Audeze LCD-MX4
comment: Classic Audeze combo of solid resolution with a confusing lack of upper midrange.

name: Focal Stellia
comment: "Harman-inspired" tuning works decently well, though a myriad of small quirks ultimately screws its tonal balance.

name: Meze Empyrean
comment: Bland and unexciting tuning with compressed staging and generally underperforming technicalities.

name: Rosson RAD-0
comment: Middling technicalities with suppressed upper midrange.

name: Pioneer SE-Master1
comment: Treble daggers applied directly into ear.

name: ZMF Verite
comment: Excellent resolution unfortunately marred by suppressed harmonics and a harsh upper-midrange.

name: ZMF Verite Closed
comment: Far more tonally balanced than its open counterpart, whilst retaining its reverberant staging.

name: Hifiman Jade II
comment: Suffers from typical estat timbre and bass extension issues, but otherwise a very resolving and well-tuned headphone.

name: Sennheiser HD820
comment: The mystical acoustic properties of Gorilla Glass could not save this monstrosity.

name: DCA Ether 2
comment: Hard to explain what exactly this sounds like, but the first thing you'd hear is probably the treble roll-off.

name: Spirit Torino Radiante
comment: Humps for days. Wouldn't be a stretch to call this "ꟿ-shaped".

name: ES Lab ES-1a
comment: Seems inspired by the tuning of the SR-009 with some minor improvements, though not enough to call it "good".

name: Timsok TS-1024
comment: Somewhat warm midrange plagued with sharp and offensive treble.

name: Audio Technica ATH-ADX5000
comment: Clean, open sound reminsicent of the HD800, with a bit of midbass bloat and upper midrange shoutiness.

name: Audeze LCD-3
comment: Classic Audeze combo of solid resolution with a confusing lack of upper midrange. Now with extra honk.

name: Audio Technica ATH-AWKT
comment: AWKT, more like AWKward... I'll leave now.

name: HEDDphone
comment: An interesting in-between of DD and estat timbre, though tuning around the lower midrange may be off.

name: DCA Ether Flow 1.1
comment: Has elements of the DT880/HD800 tuning, with extra note thickness and more piercing treble.

name: Sony MDR-Z1R
comment: Holes in the midrange. Big spike in the treble. Strangely disjointed soundstage. Decently resolving.

name: Fostex TH909
comment: A slightly more balanced TH900 with similar sibilance issues.

name: Audeze LCD-X (Pre-20201)
comment: Probably the worst tuned Audeze available. At least, this specific unit is.

name: DCA Ether C Flow 1.1
comment: Sounds like something went wrong with the upper-midrange tuning.

name: Denon AH-D9200
comment: Generally weird and wonky tuning that can also get rather harsh at times.

name: Fostex TH900
comment: Spicy sibilance and bloated bass are disappointments in what is otherwise an extremely dynamic headphone.

name: ZMF Auteur
comment: Very pleasant tonality but lacking that last bit of definition for true top-tier status.

name: Hifiman Arya
comment: High resolution planar that may be a little peaky in the treble for some.

name: AKG K812
comment: Sharp, shrill, piercing, sibilant, and all other synonyms.

name: AKG K872 Pro
comment: Strange pad shape makes for wildly-varying bass. Generally a tonally weird headphone.

name: Focal Clear Mg
comment: Lacks upper mids and resolution compared to its predecessor.

name: Audio Technica ATH-AWAS
comment: Rolled off bass with somewhat suppressed treble. Not the worst but far from being tonally balanced.

name: ZMF Eikon
comment: Hole in the mids with a sharp piercing peak in the treble.

name: Focal Radiance
comment: Probably the best of the closed-back Focals. Some tuning refinements over the Stellia, though technically limited.

name: Audeze LCD-XC
comment: Definitely the least Audeze-sounding Audeze. A little quirky tonally, but nothing too offensive.

name: Klipsch HP3
comment: Lots of bass bloat, way too thick-sounding and lacking definition.

name: Audeze LCD-X (2021)
comment: Tonally, a massive improvement over the previous version(s) though with the usual pitfalls of the Audeze house sound.

name: ZMF Aeolus
comment: Tonally, a vast improvement over the Aeolus with stock pads, bringing in extra clarity and bite.

name: ZMF Atticus
comment: Bloated bass with wonky midrange, a killer combination.

name: Beyerdynamic T1 (3rd Gen)
comment: When you answer "yes" to the question "how much lower mids do you want?"

name: Beyerdynamic T5 (3rd Gen)
comment: Wibbly-wobbly midrange with far too liberal a bass boost makes for a terrible sound.

name: Denon AH-D7200
comment: Generally weird and wonky tuning that can also get rather harsh at times.

name: Focal Elear
comment: Subdued upper midrange with the odd treble spike makes this a weird headphone to listen to.

name: Focal Elegia
comment: Severe lack of upper midrange and treble results in a muffled, dulled tone.

name: DCA Aeon 2 Open
comment: Arguably the best tuned DCA headphone with a slightly thick midrange and least offensive treble.

name: Sony MDR-Z7M2
comment: Sounds like a "Z1R-lite", with arguably better bass response but peakier treble.

name: DCA Aeon 2 Closed
comment: Passable tonality with dulled and blunted transients make for lacklustre detailing.

name: Audeze LCD-GX
comment: As a gaming headphone, possibly the best technically though with the usual pitfalls of the Audeze house sound.

name: Audeze LCD-2 Closed-back
comment: Not the worst Audeze in terms of tonality, but its tuning still doesn't live up to its technical capabilities.

name: Aurorus Borealis
comment: Sounds like an odd mashup of the HD600 and the Clear, in a good way.

name: Quad ERA-1
comment: Kind of a "nothing headphone"; not the worst thing in the world but no praises either.

name: Campfire Cascade
comment: Competent midrange tuning let down by a loose, bloated bass response.

name: Audeze LCD-2 Classic
comment: Classic Audeze combo of solid resolution with a confusing lack of upper midrange.

name: Beyerdynamic Amiron Home
comment: Mid-bass bloated and shouty at the same time.

name: Hifiman HE5SE
comment: Strong contender for an excellent headphone, if not for the inexplicable hole in the mids.

name: Denon AH-D5200
comment: Probably the least wonky of the new Denons. Suffers from some mid-bass bloat.

name: Hifiman Ananda
comment: One of the best tuned headphones available, only limited by its raw resolving ability.

name: Beyerdynamic DT1770 Pro
comment: A slightly more balanced version of the old DT770.

name: Audeze Sine DX
comment: Decent bass extension, honky midrange presentation.

name: Sendy Aiva
comment: A slightly worse-tuned B20, kinda.

name: Beyerdynamic DT1990 Pro
comment: An intense sound given its significant treble boost, but countered by a smooth lower-midrange bump.

name: Fostex TH610
comment: The most neutral of the Foster biodyna models. If you want a little more balance than the Teaks.

name: iBasso SR2
comment: Shouty, shrill and lacking the proper heft in the bass region.

name: Apple AirPods Max
comment: Great tonality, sub-focused bass emphasis, bassy without being muddy. Average imaging and resolution.

name: iBasso SR1
comment: Wonky midrange is one thing, but dying after 6kHz is another.

name: AKG K712 Pro
comment: Sizeable mid-bass bloat that's barely reigned in by an equally sizeable upper-midrange emphasis.

name: Neumann NDH 20
comment: Feels like an attempt at Harman but ultimately missing the mark in the midrange tuning.

name: Shure SRH1540
comment: Almost "Harman" tuning with some undesirable mid-bass bloat.

name: B&O BeoPlay H7
comment: Wonky, honky midrange. Not great.

name: BLON B20
comment: Basically a darker planar HD6X0, with equally closed-in staging and lacking the final resolving edge.

name: Massdrop x Koss ESP/95X
comment: Good resolving ability and imaging, marred by its odd and honky midrange.

name: AKG K701
comment: The brightest and arguably harshest of the K7-- lineup, but still very competent overall.

name: Grado The Hemp Headphone
comment: Nothing much different from your average Grado; paid extra for the novelty, not the sonic improvements.

name: Drop + THX Panda
comment: Well-tuned but with overpowering mid-bass and extremely dulled transients.

name: Shure Aonic 50
comment: A parody of the V-shaped response. Scooped mids, hollow sound.

name: Audeze LCD-1
comment: The best tuned Audeze headphone with the worst resolution.

name: Bose Noise Cancelling Headphones 700
comment: More subdued presentation compared to its precedessor, almost to the point of being boring.

name: B&W PX
comment: Warm, bloated sound with a largely muffled midrange.

name: Sennheiser HD660S
comment: An even darker HD6X0. A comparatively muffled mess just barely propped up by its decent resolving ability.

name: E-MU Teak
comment: Excellent dynamics with one of the best bass I've heard in a headphone, though the midrange can be a little harsh.

name: Sennheiser HD600
comment: The legendary neutral reference. Slightly better clarity and imaging than the HD650.

name: Sony WH-1000XM4
comment: Consumer-friendly heavy bass unfortunately bleeds into the mids, but otherwise fine.

name: Bose QuietComfort 35 II (QC35)
comment: The typical mainstream V-shape response with middling technicalities.

name: Beyerdynamic DT880 Pro
comment: Certainly a "mini-HD800" in terms of tonality only, however still far inferior in technical ability.

name: HarmonicDyne Zeus
comment: A rare combination of a warm-focused tonality with decent technicalities.

name: Sennheiser Momentum 3 Wireless
comment: A massive improvement over its predecessor. Limited resolution and potentially intense tonality.

name: Hifiman Sundara
comment: Solid tuning with a little treble spiciness for the daring. One of the better midrange planars out there.

name: AKG K702
comment: Slightly more upper-mid-forward (read: shoutier) version of the K612.

name: Audio Technica ATH-R70x
comment: Excellent imaging. Mostly neutral/flat tuning with an ever-so-slight tilt towards warmth.

name: Audio Technica ATH-EW9
comment: Forget shout; this thing screams.

name: V-MODA Crossfade 2 Wireless
comment: The typical mainstream V-shape response with middling technicalities.

name: Meze 99 Classics
comment: Just excessive bass that unfortunately screws with the tonality of the mids.

name: Focal Listen Professional
comment: Not sure if this is supposed to seal, but in the event that it isn't: why?

name: Audio Technica ATH-AD900X
comment: Extremely uneven tuning, mediocre resolution, not a great choice unless you only want a wide soundstage.

name: Audeze Mobius
comment: Not the total lack of upper midrange I expected, but a hole in the upper mids nonetheless.

name: Sony MDR-1AM2
comment: Harman-ish tuning with a strong mid-bass presence and piercing upper treble response.

name: Sivga Phoenix
comment: A fairly competent warm-neutral monitor slightly held back by limited detail retrieval.

name: Audio Technica ATH-M70x
comment: The most neutral of the M-series. Good tonality but still suffers from narrow imaging.

name: Hifiman Deva
comment: Probably the most "mellow" of the Hifiman planars with the least resolving ability.

name: Precide ERGO 2
comment: Sounds exactly like what it is: a headphone with a broken seal.

name: Harman Kardon FLY ANC
comment: Peaky, mid-bassy attempt at a Harman tuning.

name: Grado GW100
comment: Not the worst Grado, but you could still do better than Grado.

name: Master & Dynamic MH40
comment: Too much bass, and not the good kind either.

name: Audio Technica ATH-MSR7b
comment: Thin-sounding yet bloated at the same time. Intense upper midrange.

name: Audio Technica ATH-A990Z
comment: Odd cup resonance results in wonky imaging. Prefer the original A900X.

name: FiiO EH3
comment: Sounds as if the ANC is trying to cancel out its own sound.

name: Audio Technica ATH-AD700X
comment: Extremely uneven tuning, mediocre resolution, not a great choice unless you only want a wide soundstage.

name: Logitech G933s
comment: Too much bloat going on in the bass, which is a shame given that the rest of the mids are alright.

name: Beyerdynamic DT250
comment: Horrible treble extension and a honkiness that gets worse the longer you listen.

name: V-MODA Crossfade LP2
comment: Big bass, bad bass, no treble extension.

name: Sennheiser HD599
comment: A little too sharp, a little too midbassy, but overall not the most offensive headphone out there.

name: Massdrop x AKG K7XX
comment: A more bloated-sounding K712.

name: Sennheiser HD579
comment: More or less a HD599 with slightly worse resolution.

name: Sennheiser HD25 Plus
comment: Punchy, energetic sound with decently balanced tonality. A pretty good beat-tracking monitor.

name: Sennheiser HD560S
comment: Well-balanced tonality with good bass extension, just slightly hot in the upper-mids and treble.

name: Beyerdynamic DT990 Pro
comment: Pretty bog-standard V-shaped response with forward upper-midrange and decently high resolution.

name: Beyerdynamic TYGR 300 R
comment: Very reminiscent of the DT990.

name: AKG K612 Pro
comment: Basically dead-neutral tuning, emphasis on "dead". Strong all-rounder whose only fault is not having that "wow-factor".

name: Sennheiser Momentum 2.0 Wireless
comment: Probably the worst headphone Sennheiser has ever made. Yes, even the HD820.

name: HarmonicDyne Helios
comment: Lack of bass extension is its biggest dealbreaker of what would be an otherwise solid headphone.

name: Audio Technica ATH-AD500X
comment: Suppressed and uneven upper-mids, mediocre resolution, not a great choice unless you only want a wide soundstage.

name: Hifiman HE400i (2020)
comment: Well-executed reference-ish tuning with a slight treble emphasis.

name: Beyerdynamic DT770 Pro
comment: Sounds like a parody of Harman with its excessive 200Hz notch and overblown treble.

name: Koss Pro4S
comment: Horrible lower-midrange scoop screws with every instrument.

name: Sennheiser HD559
comment: Big, thick sound that muffles everything but the most surface level details.

name: Audio Technica ATH-M50x
comment: The headphone that the elites love to hate... isn't that bad. An alright starter headphone, if generally overrated.

name: Koss SP540
comment: The typical mainstream V-shape response with middling technicalities.

name: ASTRO A40 TR
comment: Middling technicalities, but for a gaming headphone its tonality is surprisingly balanced.

name: AKG K371
comment: Expectedly Harman tuning but lacks a bit of bite in the upper midrange for "true Harman".

name: Shure SRH840
comment: Extremely well-executed V-shaped tuning with no erronous peaks or dips. More mid-bassy than sub-bassy.

name: Logitech G PRO X
comment: Too much bloat going on in the bass, which is a shame given that the rest of the mids are alright.

name: Audio Technica ATH-M40x
comment: Well-balanced tonality with disappointing detailing and claustrophobic imaging.

name: E-MU Walnut
comment: Tonality is somewhat off with peaks and dips here and there, but overall not a bad sounding headphone.

name: Shure SRH440
comment: Closest thing to Harman thus far. Comes with a small upper treble spike and lacking raw resolution.

name: Koss PRO DJ100
comment: Good tuning but unfortunately weird pad shape that makes it hard to get the proper bass response.

name: Koss Portapro
comment: The KSC75 is better.

name: 1MORE MK801
comment: Smooth, generally pleasing tonality throughout with no offensive characteristics.

name: Sennheiser HD400S
comment: At least it's not the Momentum 2.0 Wireless.

name: Audio Technica ATH-M30X
comment: Scooped upper midrange with below average technicalities.

name: AKG K240 Studio
comment: Abysmal bass extension with overly-boosted lower mids makes for a strange listening experience.

name: AKG K92
comment: Hole in the bass, hole in the mids, hole in the treble. AKG's struck a turkey.

name: Shure SRH240A
comment: Compressed, honky and lacking all but the most surface-level of detailing.

name: AKG K72
comment: Hole in the bass, hole in the mids, hole in the treble. AKG's struck a turkey.

name: EKSA E900 Pro
comment: Typical cheaply-made headphone that's all bass with zero technical ability. A waste of any money.

name: AKG K52
comment: Hole in the bass, hole in the mids, hole in the treble. AKG's struck a turkey.

name: Koss KSC75
comment: Non-existent sub-bass and poor resolution. But it's so well-tuned you may not even care.

name: Yamaha HP-300
comment: Virtually no records of this exist on the internet, and maybe it's better that way.

name: Pioneer SE-2P
comment: The pads look like toilet plungers. Sounds like one too.

name: Sansui SS-10
comment: A simulation of how it's like to have hearing damage.

name: Final Sonorous VIII
comment: Quirky artisanal Japanese handiwork so quirky that they forgot that it's supposed to play music.

name: Final Sonorous X
comment: Quirky artisanal Japanese handiwork so quirky that they forgot that it's supposed to play music.

name: Yamaha HP-50S
comment: Bloated, lacking resolution, narrow imaging. Just a bad headphone all around.

name: AudioQuest NightOwl
comment: Heavily downsloped response makes the upper harmonics completely disappear.

name: Beyerdynamic DT1350
comment: Muffled, narrow-sounding, and lacking surface-level detail.

name: Logitech G431
comment: Bloated bass like the rest, but further exacerbated by the recessed midrange.

name: Sennheiser Amperior
comment: Extremely nasally vocals and lacks weight in the mids.

name: Pioneer Monitor 10
comment: Slightly honky midrange, weird uneven treble, and hard to get a proper seal.

name: Sony MDR-7510
comment: Everything just sounds strange and oddly sharp in tone, but extremely blunted in transients.

name: Stax SR-3
comment: Similarly tuned to the SR-X, albeit with a much more blunted presentation.

name: Audio Technica ATH-A1000Z
comment: Odd upper-midrange tuning results in a scratchy, uneven presentation.

name: Audio Technica ATH-A2000Z
comment: Odd upper-midrange tuning results in a scratchy, uneven presentation.

name: SR60e/
comment: Forward, almost nasally midrange with an intense treble response.

name: Sony MDR-V6
comment: Somewhat thin-sound and shouty but overall a very well-tuned set, if extremely blunted and narrow in imaging.

name: Oppo PM-3
comment: Fairly well-tuned, if very technically limited in both resolution and imaging performance.

name: Stax SR-40
comment: One of the few Stax electrets out there. Not great in tonality nor technical performance.

name: Sony MDR-CD900ST
comment: Solid dark-ish reference tuning, with the usual V6/7506-esque absence of soundstage.

name: Stax SR-84/
comment: Surprisingly coherent tuning for what is effectively an unsealed electret. Lacks too much resolution.

name: Stax SR-X Mk2
comment: Surprisingly good tonal balance marred by its complete absence of bass response.

name: Audio Technica ATH-A900X
comment: Subdued upper mids and enhanced mid-bass. If anything else, this is a headphone that wouldn't fatigue.

name: Beyerdynamic DT860
comment: Upwards-sloping bright and lean sound.

name: Focal Celestee
comment: Thin and uneven mids with narrow, congested staging.

name: AudioQuest NightHawk
comment: Thick, grand, heavy... muddy.

name: Audio Technica ATH-AD1000X
comment: Quirky tuning with imbalanced upper harmonics. Similar to that of the AD2000.

name: Audio Technica ATH-AD2000
comment: Quirky tuning with imbalanced upper harmonics. Similar to that of the AD1000X.

name: Fostex TH500
comment: An interesting oldschool planar, vastly outpaced by today's market.

name: Philips SHP9500
comment: Decent imaging chops held back by its intensely bright presentation and below-average resolution.

name: Audio Technica ATH-A2000X
comment: Somewhat mid-centric runing that's far too coloured for its own good.

name: MrSpeakers Aeon Flow/
comment: Reminds of the NightHawk a bit, except with far worse resolution.

name: Acoustic Research AR-H1
comment: A tempered, almost bright-leaning planar (but not quite). Decent tonality and technical ability.

name: Beyerdynamic T5p (1st Gen)
comment: Choppy midrange response is its biggest turnoff, but otherwise a decent V-shaped headphone.

name: Fostex TH7
comment: Fairly neutral monitor-style headphone with poor imaging and detail retrieval.

name: SR-009/
comment: Detail and resolution worthy of being called "the best", marred by the tonally-off midrange.

name: Audeze LCD-4
comment: A classic example of a highly resolving yet wonky sounding headphone. Needs more upper midrange.

name: Sony MDR-MA900
comment: Imaging as expected of an earspeaker configuration; surprisingly good tonality and expected bad extension.

name: Abyss AB-1266 Phi CC
comment: Sinfully addictive bass and treble reponse, but the midrange tonality needs a lot of work.

name: Sony MDR-CD380
comment: Shouty and thin-sounding, though surprisingly competent imaging ability.

name: Hifiman HE500
comment: Perhaps the warmest of the Hifiman lineup. Not the most resolving.

name: Abyss Diana Phi
comment: Needs a little more upper midrange to balance out the honkiness. Good dynamic performance especially in the bass.

name: Fostex TR80
comment: A very well-tuned monitor-style headphone, if heavily bottlenecked by narrow imaging and blunt hits.

name: Stax SR-L300
comment: Generally pleasing tuning, though a little honky and fatiguing in the treble.

name: Hifiman HE6se
comment: Comes with an odd midrange dip. It's no HE6 replacement for sure.

name: RAAL-requisite SR1a
comment: Weak, limp bass is the killing blow for what is an otherwise highly resolving and decently-tuned earspeaker.

name: (V1)/
comment: Slight wonkiness around the lower midrange, but otherwise a capable planar headphone.

name: Stax SR-L700
comment: Probably the most balanced tuning of the L-series, with the usual e-stat technicalities.

name: Stax SR-L300 Limited/
comment: Honkier version of the standard L300.

name: Sony MDR-SA5000
comment: Surprisingly competent for a decades-old set. Midrange is a little uneven but beats out many other modern TOTLs.

name: Hifiman HE5
comment: The original Hifiman. Midrange is a little too scooped out but remains competitive even today.

name: Denon AH-D5000
comment: The usual "Foster biodyna dynamics" are at play here, with a somewhat fatiguing treble spike.

name: Kennerton Odin
comment: Generally "okay" tonality with some odd dips here and there. Lacking serious extension for a planar.

name: Kennerton Thror
comment: Kind of a "nothing headphone"; not bad, not great, just good enough to be okay.

name: Stax SR-404
comment: Similar tuning to that of the Lambda Pro. Sonically identical between 404 and 404LE.

name: Stax SR-507
comment: Similar tuning to that of the Lambda Pro.

name: Hifiman HE6
comment: Clean, resolving yet intense sound scratches the detail itch but is a little too edgy for long listens.

name: Stax SR-4070
comment: Surprisingly wide and spacious soundstage for a closed-back. Good low-end extension but rather shouty.
The legendary neutral reference. "Veiled" with a warm tilt (in comparison to HD600), and pretty terrible at imaging.

name: HD800/
comment: Arguably the king of soundstage and raw detail, though at the cost of its infamous treble spike.

name: Beyerdynamic T70
comment: Treble peak may offend some, but otherwise very well balanced and natural tonality with decent technicalities.

name: MrSpeakers Ether C
comment: Forward, in-your-face sound that's shouty and thin at the same time. A good reference for "true DF neutral".

name: Stax SR-L500
comment: Generally pleasing tuning with a little honkiness in the centre-midrange.

name: Hifiman Edition X V2
comment: Excellent tonal balance though limited by blunted notes and resolution.

name: Stax SR-Lambda Pro
comment: One of the original Lambda models, and arguably the best tuned of the Lambda-styled Staxes.

name: Stax SR-007
comment: Arguably the least wonky-sounding of the mainstream Staxes, with resolution just shy of the flagship 009.

name: Nectar Hive
comment: Some spiciness in the treble that is HD800-esque, but with a better midrange presentation.

name: Focal Clear
comment: A decent Utopia alternative for thinner wallets. Slightly warmer sound may be more pleasant for some.

name: Hifiman HE1000
comment: A planar that comes unnervingly close estat speed, but not quite. Solid technicalities with excellent tone.
